review.title: Identifying reasoning patterns in games
review.abstract: We present an algorithm that identifies the reasoning patterns of agents in a game, by iteratively examining the graph structure of its Multi-Agent Influence Diagram (MAID) representation. If the decision of an agent participates in no reasoning patterns, then we can effectively ignore that decision for the purpose of calculating a Nash equilibrium for the game. In some cases, this can lead to exponential time savings in the process of equilibrium calculation. Moreover, our algorithm can be used to enumerate the reasoning patterns in a game, which can be useful for constructing more effective computerized agents interacting with humans.

metadata.title: Identifying reasoning patterns in games

sections.text: We present an algorithm that identifies the thinking patterns of agents in a game by iteratively examining the graph structure of its Multi-Agent Influence Diagram (MAID) representation. If an agent's decision is not involved in any thinking patterns, we can effectively ignore this decision to calculate a Nash balance for the game. In some cases, this can result in exponential time savings in the process of equilibrium calculation. In addition, our algorithm can be used to enumerate the thinking patterns in a game, which can be useful to construct more effective computer-assisted agents that interact with humans.

sections.heading: 3 SIMPLIFYING MAIDs
sections.text: In this section, we present an algorithm for identifying unmotivated nodes, which allows us to simplify a MAID M and render a simplified version of it. It works by iteratively passing through two phases: the first (lines 6-17) is a rationalization phase in which for each decision the algorithm tries to determine that it is motivated, i.e., at least one rationing pattern holds for it. Unmotivated decision nodes are those in which every action taken has no effect on decision-making, and these decisions are removed by random nodes with uniform conditional probability distributions and any edges that come to them. The second phase (lines 18-20) is a marginal phase in which no impact on the decision of the decision-maker.

sections.heading: 4 AN EXAMPLE
sections.text: Consider the game A, which can be either high (H), medium (M) or low (L. Another player (B) has to guess what kind of card A was dealt; on a correct guess he wins 10 dollars, otherwise he gets nothing, which is the true value of the card. Finally, another player has access to the values of the card and has to guess what B's guessed, he wins 10 dollars, otherwise he gets nothing before making his decision.

sections.heading: 6 DISCUSSION
sections.text: The algorithm presented in this paper uses the adoption of well-differentiated (WD) strategies to simplify a game in order to calculate a Nash balance. Although this is a reasonable assumption for computer agents, it is not clear whether humans generally condition their actions only on the basis of observations that have an impact on their usefulness, or if they otherwise take irrelevant signals to heart. We plan to investigate these experimentally. Another limitation of our algorithm is that it uses strictly graphical properties to detect and remove unmotivated nodes. Although this greatly simplifies the process and keeps it computationally efficient, a more rigorous examination of the parameters within random and utility nodes could lead to further simplifications. For example, it could be the case that a signal-logical thought pattern keeps graphical, but the parameters of the MAID are such that the first agent (Alice) always optimally decides on a particular action for all possible values as a response.

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSION & FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We have presented an algorithm for identifying reasoning patterns in games. It can be used in two ways: first, it can identify unmotivated decisions in a MAID diagram; these can be effectively ignored to calculate a Nash balance that can sometimes lead to significant computational savings; second, it can detect non-obvious patterns of thought agents that could be used in decision-making; these patterns can be presented to a human decision maker to help him or her make good decisions; and it can be used as input for other algorithms to dissect, analyze, explain, or even predict agents or human behavior. We believe that in complex systems, especially those where human and computer agents interact strongly, it is important for successful agents to model the "context" of their interaction. Certain features of games are likely to provoke different motivations in human behavior, such as reciprocity or cooperation.
